data.description: 13,000 years ago, this site was well-known by mammoth hunters as a source of flint for tools. Centuries passed, but the colorful flint never lost its value or usefulness in the Texas Panhandle. Learn how important this site was to the survival, commerce and culture of the people of the High Plains.

entranceFees.description: All services and programs are free.
entranceFees.title: Alibates Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: There is no fee or pass required for use of this park.
entrancePasses.title: Monument Pass

data.directionsInfo: Alibates Flint Quarries is located approximately 35 miles north of Amarillo, Texas. From I-40 in Amarillo, take Lakeside exit north towards Lake Meredith National Recreation Area. Exit on TX 136 north towards Borger. After about 30 miles, turn west from TX 136 onto Cas Johnson Road. Park Service signs will be visible. Proceed approximately 3 miles to "Y" intersection and bear to right. Go northwest approximately 2 miles to the Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument Visitor Center.

operatingHours.description: Alibates Flint Quarries Visitor Center is open every day of the year except Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.
operatingHours.name: Monument Operating Hours

images.title: Turtle Petroglyph
images.altText: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site
images.caption: Turtle Petroglyph at Antelope Creek Village Site

images.title: Alibates Visitor Center
images.altText: A view of the gardens and Alibates Visitor Center.
images.caption: The gardens and Alibates Visitor Center host activities and ranger-led programs throughout the year.

images.title: Alibates Flint
images.altText: Colorful chunks of Alibates Flint.
images.caption: Used for at least 13,000 years, Alibates Flint was the choice of many tribes for their stone tools, spearpoints and arrowheads.

images.title: Alibates Flint Quarries Trail
images.altText: Stair steps up the Alibates Flint Quarries Trail.
images.caption: Take a hike up the Quarries Trail to learn about this important stone.

images.title: Snowy Alibates
images.altText: A snowy mesa, as seen from the Alibates Visitor Center.
images.caption: Every season hold special beauty at Alibates Flint Quarries National Monument.

data.weatherInfo: The Texas Panhandle experiences a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, and summers are hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to bring a jacket with you if you are planning on hiking to the quarries with a ranger because the mesa gets very windy, even in the summer.
data.name: Alibates Flint Quarries

data.description: An oasis in the desert, Amistad National Recreation Area consists of the US portion of the International Amistad Reservoir. Amistad, whose name comes from the Spanish word meaning friendship, is best known for excellent water-based recreation, camping, hiking, rock art viewing, and its rich cultural history. Amistad is also home to a wide variety of plant and animal life above and below the water.

entranceFees.description: There is no park entrance fee. However, there are fees associated with camping and launching motorized boats. The park only accepts payment of these fees by credit or debit card.
entranceFees.title: There is no entrance fee at Amistad National Recreation Area

entrancePasses.description: If you are using a motorized boat on the lake you will need to purchase a Lake Use Pass. They can be purchased at the Visitor Center or by using the fee machines located at Diablo East, Box Canyon, Rough Canyon, and campgrounds. All purchases are by credit or debit only.
entrancePasses.title: Daily Lake Use Pass

entrancePasses.description:
If you are using a motorized boat on the lake you will need to purchase a Lake Use Pass. They can be purchased at the Visitor Center or by using the fee machines located at Diablo East, Box Canyon, Rough Canyon, and at campgrounds. All purchases are by credit or debit only.

**Yearly Lake Use Passes purchased at the fee machines are temporary yearly passes and must be exchanged for a boat sticker at the Visitor Center.**
entrancePasses.title: Yearly Lake Use Pass

data.directionsInfo: Six miles west of the HWY 90 and 277 North intersection at 10477 Highway 90 West.

operatingHours.description: Amistad National Recreation Area is open throughout the year. However, some areas may experience temporary closures because of low water levels. Please see our Operation Hours and Seasons and Current Conditions pages for more specific details.
operatingHours.name: Amistad National Recreation Area

images.title: View of Amistad National Recreation Area from The Diablo East Nature Trail
images.altText: Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Blue skies and blue waters are common at Amistad National Recreation Area

images.title: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.altText: Under the HWY 90 Bridge
images.caption: A view of the Amistad Reservoir and the HWY 90 Bridge from Governors Landing.

images.title: The shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: A view of the peaceful shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: A peaceful view of the shores along Amistad National Recreation Area

images.title: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: Sunset over Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: The ever chainging and beautiful sunsets in Southwest Texas are one of the many things visitor enjoy while at Amistad National Recreation Area.

images.title: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.altText: Limestone shoreline along Amistad National Recreation Area
images.caption: Limestone is visible along the shoreline of Amistad National Recreation Area.

data.weatherInfo: Weather in Southwest Texas can change in a matter of minutes. It is best to check the local weather report. Amistad National Recreation Area usually has hot summers and mild winters. For more information, please visit our Current Conditions page at https://www.nps.gov/amis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm.
data.name: Amistad

data.description: There is a place in Far West Texas where night skies are dark as coal and rivers carve temple-like canyons in ancient limestone. Here, at the end of the road, hundreds of bird species take refuge in a solitary mountain range surrounded by weather-beaten desert. Tenacious cactus bloom in sublime southwestern sun, and diversity of species is the best in the country. This magical place is Big Bend...

entranceFees.description: This fee includes all occupants of a private, non-commercial vehicle and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Per Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one motorcycle; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Fee applicable to one individual walking in or bicycling in and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend Entrance Fee--Individual

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 15 or less pay a per vehicle fee.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity 15 or less

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups with a vehicle capacity of 16 or more pay a $12.00 per person fee. Children 15 and younger are free. Annual and lifetime passes may be used.
entranceFees.title: Non-commercial groups with vehicle capacity of 16 or more

entranceFees.description: $12 per client; passes may not be used. Business is required to obtain commercial use authorization. Bus tours, 25 person capacity or greater, $200 (commercial use authorization not required).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Group Fee

entrancePasses.description: The Big Bend Annual Pass covers entrance fees to Big Bend National Park. Pass is available at Big Bend National Park entrance stations or the Panther Junction Visitor Center. Pass is non-transferable.
entrancePasses.title: Big Bend Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, food, water, and supplies for your trip. There are no electric vehicle charging stations in Big Bend National Park. The closest EV charging station is 130 miles away in Fort Stockton.

operatingHours.description: Big Bend National Park is always open. You can enter and exit at any time of the day or night. Park entrances are open 24 hours daily, all year.
operatingHours.name: Big Bend National Park

images.title: Blooming Cenizo
images.altText: Blooming Cenizo
images.caption: Cenizo, or Big Bend Silverleaf blossoms after summer rains.

images.title: Century Plant Agave
images.altText: Century Plant Agave
images.caption: Century Plants bloom only once in their long lives.

images.title: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.altText: Vermilion Flycatcher
images.caption: Big Bend is home to over 450 species of birds!

images.title: Fascinating Geology
images.altText: Fascinating Geology
images.caption: Volcanic features abound near Castolon

images.title: Desert Scenery
images.altText: Desert Scenery
images.caption: Big Bend is a prime example of Chihuahuan Desert

images.title: Santa Elena Canyon
images.altText: Santa Elena Canyon
images.caption: Santa Elena Canyon

images.title: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.altText: View from the South Rim of the Chisos
images.caption: Big Bend is a place of expansive views

images.title: Rio Grande Scene
images.altText: Rio Grande Scene
images.caption: The Rio Grande serves as the park's southern boundary

images.title: Blooming Ocotillo
images.altText: Blooming Ocotillo
images.caption: When ocotillo bloom, they transform the desert

images.title: Balanced Rock
images.altText: Balanced Rock
images.caption: The balanced rock is a popular day hiking destination.

images.title: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.altText: Top of the Lost Mine Trail
images.caption: Hiking the Lost Mine Trail affords many amazing views.

images.title: Chisos Mountains
images.altText: Chisos Mountains
images.caption: The Chisos Mountains rise above the desert

data.weatherInfo: Big Bend is a desert park, so be prepared for extreme conditions. SPRING: From February through April the park abounds with pleasant and comfortable temperatures. SUMMER: May through September is very hot. Temperatures will exceed 100 degrees in the lower elevations by late morning, and often exceed 110 along the Rio Grande. Afternoon thunderstorms can be a welcome respite. WINTER: October through January temperatures are cooler; the weather can quickly turn cold at any time during these months.
data.name: Big Bend

data.description: Life of all types abounds in the Big Thicket. This national preserve protects the incredible diversity of life found where multiple habitats meet in southeast Texas. Hiking trails and waterways meander through nine different ecosystems, from longleaf pine forests to cypress-lined bayous. It is a place of discovery, a place to wander and explore, a place to marvel at the richness of nature.

emailAddresses.description: We usually reply to emails within one week.

entranceFees.description: Big Thicket National Preserve does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Free Admission

data.directionsInfo: The main corridor through the Big Thicket is US Hwy 69/287 between Beaumont and Woodville. Many smaller roads and highways branch off of the main corridor to reach trailheads and scenic areas. The visitor center is located at the intersection of US 69/287 and FM 420, about 7 miles north of Kountze and 30 miles north of Beaumont.

operatingHours.description: Big Thicket National Preserve is open 24 hours. To camp in the preserve, you need a backcountry camping permit, available from the visitor center.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

images.title: Cypress Swamp
images.altText: Bright green swamp with shallow water and many kinds of trees and jungle-like plants.
images.caption: When you think of Texas, do you picture jungle-like swamps?

images.title: Staley Cabin
images.altText: A log cabin in a forest beneath a canopy of sprawling live oak trees.
images.caption: Historic Staley Cabin sits at the start of the Kirby Nature Trail.

images.title: Canoe on Lake Bayou
images.altText: A park ranger paddling a green canoe on a slow-moving waterway below cypress trees.
images.caption: A canoe or kayak trip is the best way to see Big Thicket's waterways.

images.title: Beaver Slide Trail Bridge
images.altText: A small wooden bridge on a trail through dense woods.
images.caption: Wander through the woods on the Beaver Slide Trail.

images.title: Pitcher Plant
images.altText: Close-up of a carnivorous pitcher plant with the shadow of an insect inside.
images.caption: Visit in spring to see carnivorous pitcher plants.

images.title: Red-Headed Woodpecker
images.altText: A woodpecker with bright red head clinging to a dead tree.
images.caption: Look for woodpeckers in Big Thicket's pine forests.

images.title: Village Creek Bridge
images.altText: An iron bridge above a murky creek surrounded by dense woods.
images.caption: The bridge over Village Creek connects the Kirby Nature Trail to the Turkey Creek Trail.

images.title: Cypress Knees
images.altText: Shadowy-looking cypress knees and their reflections in still water.
images.caption: Cypress knees, extensions of bald cypresses' roots, are abundant in Big Thicket waters.

images.title: Cooks Lake Paddlers
images.altText: 2 people in a canoe and 1 person in a kayak paddle through a forested slough.
images.caption: Paddle beneath a canopy of cypress and tupelo on the Cooks Lake to Scatterman Paddling Trail.

images.title: Sundew Trail
images.altText: A wooden boardwalk curving through dense ferns and pines.
images.caption: The Sundew Trail leads hikers through a wetland pine savannah.

images.title: Fall Swamp
images.altText: Tall trees in a swamp, displaying bright orange foliage.
images.caption: Visit in November to see bald cypress leaves turn a rich orange hue.

images.title: Anole on Palmetto
images.altText: A green anole lizard resting on an outstretched palmetto leaf.
images.caption: The beauty of the Big Thicket lies in its small details.

images.title: Kirby Oak
images.altText: Sunlight poking through the canopy of a sprawling oak tree.
images.caption: Large live oaks welcome hikers to the Kirby Nature Trail.

data.weatherInfo: SPRING: Expect comfortable weather in Mar/Apr, with heat & humidity increasing in May. SUMMER: High heat, high humidity, and thunderstorms are common. Hurricane & tropical storm activity peaks in late summer. FALL: Early fall can be hot, while Oct/Nov bring pleasant temperatures. WINTER: Mild, chilly weather with occasional cold spells. Snow is rare, though Dec/Jan/Feb nights may dip below freezing.
data.name: Big Thicket

data.description: Built in 1909, the Blackwell School served as a segregated school for the Hispanic population of Marfa, Texas, during the era of de facto segregation from 1889-1965. This site will help preserve and share stories from a time when the practice of “separate but equal” dominated education and social systems in the United States.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to enter.
entranceFees.title: No Admission Fee

data.directionsInfo: The Blackwell School is located at the corner of Waco and Abbott Streets in South Marfa Texas. From the 4-way stop light, go two blocks west and three blocks south.

operatingHours.description: The unit is designated but not yet established and has very limited services. Open every Saturday and Sunday 12:00 to 4:00 p.m. And by appointment by emailing blackwellschoolmarfa@gmail.com.
operatingHours.name: All Park

images.title: Blackwell School East Exterior
images.altText: cream colored building with two windows and a wooden doorway with steps leading up to it.
images.caption: Blackwell School National Historic Site at sunrise.

data.weatherInfo: Marfa experiences long and hot summers from May – September. The winters are cold and windy with occasional light snow due to its elevation from November – February. Spring and fall offer pleasant temperatures and light rainfall.
data.name: Blackwell School

data.description: Chamizal is more than just an urban park to recreate or enjoy a quiet afternoon. These grounds are a reminder of the harmonious settlement of a 100-year boundary dispute between the United States and Mexico. We celebrate the cultures of the borderlands to promote the same mutual respect that helped to diplomatically resolve an international disagreement.

entranceFees.description: Chamizal National Memorial is a fee-free park.  There is no entrance fee for the park grounds or Cultural Center exhibit. Programs and events sponsored or presented by the Memorial's park rangers are free to the general public.
entranceFees.title: Chamizal Entrance and Sponsored Programs

data.directionsInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is located in a large, bi-national metropolitan area and easily accessible by road. El Paso International Airport is nearby, as well as an Amtrack train station.

operatingHours.description: The Memorial grounds are open to vehicle and foot traffic only when the gates are open.
operatingHours.name: Entrance Gates and Memorial Grounds

images.title: Mountain View
images.altText: a bench next to a tree with U.S. and Mexican flags flying against a mountain background
images.caption: Chamizal National Memorial stands as a reminder of the effectiveness of diplomacy and the power of friendship.

images.title: Junior Rangers
images.altText: a group of children with hand raised in front of park rangers and ground squirrel mascot
images.caption: Junior Rangers learn about Chamizal National Memorial.

images.title: Trails
images.altText: walking trails cross a field of green grass with mountain in the background
images.caption: Enjoy the green space of Chamizal in the heart of El Paso.

images.title: Theater Performances
images.altText: Women in swirling skirts and men with sombreros and colorful ponchos dance onstage
images.caption: Take in a theater performance such as this ballet folklorico.

images.title: Franklin G. Smith Gallery
images.altText: paintings hang from art gallery walls
images.caption: Browse art from the borderland in the Franklin G. Smith Gallery.

data.weatherInfo: Chamizal National Memorial is open year-round, but periodic winter weather conditions may cause closure. Please check for alerts on the park website: www.nps.gov/cham. Thunderstorms typically occur during summer and early fall. There may be no shelter to avoid lightning, so please prepare by looking at weather forecasts and paying attention to developing weather conditions.
data.name: Chamizal

data.fullName: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
data.description: Travel along El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail to experience and learn from a complicated legacy of 300 years of conflict, cooperation, and cultural exchange between a variety of empires—European and non-European alike.

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for El Camino Real. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites along El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail over the 404-mile U.S. historic route (with thousands of additional miles in Mexico) that crosses New Mexico and Texas.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Beyond the United States, the trail reaches Mexico City, Mexico. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

images.title: Kuaua Ruin in Coronado Historic Site, Bernalillo, New Mexico
images.altText: tan-colored pueblo Indian ruins with blue sky and three people
images.caption: The Tiwa pueblo of Kuaua lies in ruin at Coronado Historic Site. The site includes a rebuilt kiva that displays reproductions of original murals adorning its walls. Be sure to go to the visitor center where some of the original murals are displayed.

images.title: El Rancho de las Golondrinas, La Cienega, New Mexico
images.altText: adobe buildings including two beehive-looking ovens with people in a courtyard
images.caption: El Rancho de las Golondrinas was a historic paraje (stopping place) along El Camino Real. “The ranch of the swallows” dates from the early 1700s, and is now being used as a living history museum.

images.title: Jornada del Muerto, County Roads A013 & E070, Sierra & Doña Ana Counties, New Mexico
images.altText: shrubby desert scene with people walking under a cloud-filled sky
images.caption: Walk in the footsteps of settlers from the 1600s who had to walk along this dreaded yet unavoidable section of El Camino Real: Jornada del Muerto or Dead Man’s Journey.

images.title: Fort Selden Historic Site, Radium Springs, New Mexico
images.altText: fort ruins in the sunlight with cottonwood trees on the left
images.caption: Fort Selden was built near the town of Las Cruces in 1865 and housed troops for 25 years. The visitor center offers exhibits on frontier military life during the fort’s heyday and the grounds are self-guided.

images.title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario, Mission Trail, El Paso, Texas
images.altText: large white chapel under blue sky
images.caption: Spanish troops built a presidio (fort) and chapel at this site during the 1780s to protect settlements in the lower Río Grande Valley downstream from El Paso, Texas.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro

data.fullName: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
data.description: Explore a diverse array of histories contained within El Camino Real de los Tejas’ 150-year life, including the Spanish struggle to missionize American Indian nations, the growth of cattle ranching in the Mexican period, and the movement for Texan independence and statehood.

entranceFees.description: There are no user or entry fees for El Camino Real. Fees may be charged at some trail-related federal, state, or locally owned historic sites and interpretive facilities. Please contact individual trail sites before visiting for more information.
entranceFees.title: Entrance fees vary site by site

data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail over the 2,580-mile historic route that crosses 2 states, and travels into Mexico, to Mexico City.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de los Tejas National Historic Trail

images.title: Mission San Bernardo ruins, Guerrero, Coahuila, Mexico
images.altText: Mexican mission stands in the dirt
images.caption: Construction of the mission church began in 1760 but was never completed. The outstanding ruins are virtually the only visible remains of the complex of missions established in the area. The purpose was to convert Coahuiltecan Indians to Catholicism.

images.title: El Paso de Jacinto/Paso de los Indios, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: lots of greenery along a river; sunflowers in the foreground
images.caption: Around 1746, explorer Jacinto de León discovered a ford that allowed safe passage across the Río Grande in this vicinity; it had probably been used for centuries by American Indians.

images.title: Rancho los Ojuelos, Webb County, Texas
images.altText: stone house ruins; briliant green grasses and trees on the right
images.caption: This national historic district consists of 13 stone houses (several in ruins) constructed from hewn sandstone blocks, chinked and plastered, ranging from rectangular flat roofed Colonial style buildings to hip roofed two room structures. Post-1750s.

images.title: McKinney Falls State Park, Travis County, Texas
images.altText: rock indentations in a dry creek with five people walking under clouds
images.caption: Recent research reveals that in 1716 the expedition of Domingo Ramón followed the left bank of Onion Creek along the western edge of McKinney Falls State Park to its junction with Williamson Creek. You can walk in rock indentations in the creek bed.

images.title: Mission Tejas State Park, Houston County, Texas
images.altText: trail segment indentation with leaves in it, trees along the side
images.caption: This 1.5-mile-long trail segment crosses an area that has remarkable visual integrity. The trail segment courses parallel to State Road 21 and at times crosses the highway.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino de los Tejas National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: El Camino Real de los Tejas

data.description: Fort Davis is one of the best surviving examples of an Indian Wars' frontier military post in the Southwest. From 1854 to 1891, Fort Davis was strategically located to protect emigrants, mail coaches, and freight wagons on the Trans-Pecos portion of the San Antonio-El Paso Road and on the Chihuahua Trail.

entranceFees.description: Per Person Fee over 15 years of age. 7 Day pass
entranceFees.title: Option #1 Fort Davis Entrance Fee - Per Person

entranceFees.description: All visitors within a non-commercial vehicle included. Visitors under 16 years of age are always Free. Per person fee may be more affordable for two adults. 7 day pass.
entranceFees.title: Option #2 Fort Davis Entrance Fee - Per Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This fee is for 2 adults on one motorcycle. Per person fee may be more affordable for one adult. 7 day pass.
entranceFees.title: Option #3 Fort Davis Entrance Fee - Per Motorcycle

entrancePasses.description: You can buy an annual pass to Fort Davis National Historic Site for $35.00. This pass will admit the pass owners and three other adults to the Fort for 12 months from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Fort Davis Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: We are approximately 2.5 hours south of Midland/Odessa starting on I-20 to HWY 17, 3.5 hours North West of Del Rio starting on HWY 90 to HWY 118, 4 hours east of El Paso starting on I-10 to HWY 118 and 7 hours west of San Antonio starting on I-10 to HWY 17.

exceptions.name: Closed Martin Luther King, Jr. Day

operatingHours.description:
Daily Hours are 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM
Holiday Closures: Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day, and Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday.
operatingHours.name: Regular Hours

images.title: Parade Ground
images.altText: Garrison Flag flying over the post.
images.caption: Garrison flag flying over the post within the box canyon Fort Davis is located.

images.title: Artillery Crew
images.altText: Artillery Crew stands at the ready
images.caption: The Artillery Crew stand ready for orders to post at their positions and fire the U.S. 3-inch Ordnance Rifle.

images.title: Kitchen
images.altText: Two ladies working in the kitchen
images.caption: Special events bring back the smells of an 1800s Kitchen

images.title: Cavalry
images.altText: Soldier mounted on his horse
images.caption: The U.S. Cavalry was utilized at Fort Davis for most of its existence. Here a soldier shows off the uniform and equipment of the 1800s.

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: Building and trees at Fort Davis during the fall with yellow leaves.
images.caption: This sky island habitat is known for its dramatic season changes. Fall brings the end of our rainy season allowing the bright yellow Cottonwoods to shine. In spring /summer waving grasses and wildflowers show off their vivid colors once again.

data.weatherInfo: Summer Temperatures average a High of 95 and low of 65. Winter Temperatures average a High of 60 and a low of 20. Wind is very common and heavy rainfall is very sporadic.
data.name: Fort Davis

data.description: Come experience mountains and canyons, desert and dunes, night skies and spectacular vistas within a place unlike any other. Guadalupe Mountains National Park protects the world's most extensive Permian fossil reef, the four highest peaks in Texas, an environmentally diverse collection of flora and fauna, and the stories of lives shaped through conflict, cooperation and survival.

emailAddresses.description: Please note that most questions can be answered via the park website or on the NPS App.

entranceFees.description:
An entrance fee of $10 per person (16 years of age and older) is required; entrance fees/passes permit 1-7 consecutive days of use in this national park.

Holders of the Annual, Senior, Military, 4th grade and Access Pass can bring in 3 adults free of charge under their pass. Any pass must be displayed in a vehicle while in the national park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entrancePasses.description: This pass is valid for entrance into Guadalupe Mountains National Park for one year from the month of purchase. The pass admits up to four adults in a private vehicle and is non-transferable; visitors under 16 years of age are free. You can purchase this pass at the Pine Springs Visitor Center.
entrancePasses.title: Guadalupe Mountains National Park Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: Guadalupe Mountains National Park is located on the north side of US Hwy 62/180. If you are traveling east from El Paso, TX, we are 110 miles East of the city. Follow US Hwy 62/180 North to the Pine Springs Visitor Center. If you are traveling from Van Horn, TX, you will travel north on US 54 and make a right-hand turn at the junction of US 62/180 to arrive at the park. If you are traveling west from Carlsbad, NM, you will travel on US Hwy 62/180 South and cross into Texas. Follow signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: The Pine Springs area, including the campground, visitor center, trailhead, and associated parking areas are open and accessible all of the time during normal operations. Camping is permitted in designated campsites only.
operatingHours.name: Pine Springs

operatingHours.description:
Located on the remote west side of the park, these striking dunes cover nearly 2,000 acres. The Salt Basin Dunes are designated day use only and are accessible for visitation beginning at sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset. Camping is specifically prohibited.

The surface of the access road is clay. During rainy weather, the road becomes dangerously slippery; it is unsafe to travel when wet. The speed limit is 25 miles per hour. Watch for livestock on the roadway.
operatingHours.name: Salt Basin Dunes

operatingHours.description: McKittrick Canyon is designated as day-use only, with visiting hours from 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. (Mountain Time) daily. Please exit McKittrick Canyon before the posted closing time. The entrance gate on U.S.Highway 62/180 is locked each evening.
operatingHours.name: McKittrick Canyon

operatingHours.description: The Frijole Ranch Road provides access to the Frijole Horse Campsites, the Frijole Ranch History Museum, and the associated trailhead. A picnic area is located at the end of the road. Camping is permitted in designated campsites only.
operatingHours.name: Frijole Ranch

operatingHours.description: Dog Canyon lies in a secluded, forested canyon on the north end of the park at an elevation of 6,300 feet. Remote and far removed from civilization; it stands at the edge of the wilderness boundary, and offers an ideal location for quiet camping, birding, hiking, and solitude. A visitor center, trailhead, and campground are available. The Dog Canyon district is open all day during normal park operations.
operatingHours.name: Dog Canyon

images.caption: Blossoming claret cup cacti add a splash of color to the Chihuahuan desert.

images.caption: After the monsoon storms, the salt flats will often become flooded creating a seasonal lake.

images.caption: Changing maple trees line the Devil's Hall trail during the fall months.

images.caption: Pratt Cabin is nestled in McKittrick Canyon with abundant trees and

images.caption: During the spring months, wildflowers are a common sight along The Bowl trail.

images.altText: A metal and stone entrance sign stands in front of a building and desert mountains
images.caption: Entrance sign at Pine Springs

data.weatherInfo: The Guadalupe Mountains are known for high winds year-round; gusts can reach 60MPH or higher. In winter the mountains experiences occasional, light snowfalls which seldom last more than a day. From May through October, temperatures vary with highs between 80F-100F+ with lows in the 40F-60F range. November to April is generally milder with highs in between 50F-70F with lows in the 30F-50F range. Elevations above 8,000’ will be about 10F cooler than headquarters, with corresponding wind-chill.
data.name: Guadalupe Mountains

data.description: Within the dry plains of the Texas Panhandle lies a hidden oasis, a haven where wildlife and people find relief from the dry grasslands above. Through this plain, the Canadian River has cut dramatic 200-foot canyons, or breaks, where humans lived many years ago. Lake Meredith occupies these hidden coves and is a haven for migratory birds and other wildlife.

entranceFees.description: Fee for entering Lake Meredith National Recreation Area
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

data.directionsInfo: There are several ways to arrive at Lake Meredith. If you are coming from Amarillo, exit Loop 335 North, then exit Hwy 136 North to Fritch, Texas. Headquarters is located at 419 E. Broadway in Fritch. If coming from the North, take FM 1913 from the Dumas Highway or FM 1913 from US 287. The Amarillo Airport is approximately 35 miles south of Lake Meredith, if traveling by air. Rental cars are available in Amarillo.

operatingHours.description: The National Recreation Area is open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: Park Operating Hours

operatingHours.description: Office hours for park headquarters, including the Superintendent's office.
operatingHours.name: Park Headquarters Offices

data.weatherInfo: This area of the Texas Panhandle has a wide variety of weather conditions throughout the year. Winters are cold and windy, with summers being hot and dry. It is usually a good idea to check the weather report and dress accordingly.
data.name: Lake Meredith

data.fullName: Lyndon B Johnson National Historical Park
data.description: ---Lyndon Baines Johnson Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park tells the story of our 36th President beginning with his ancestors until his final resting place on his beloved LBJ Ranch. This entire "circle of life" gives the visitor a unique perspective into one of America's most noteworthy citizens by providing the most complete picture of any American president.

entranceFees.description: The park does not charge an entrance fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

data.directionsInfo: By car to National Park Headquarters and the Visitor Center in Johnson City: From Austin, take Highway 290 west. From San Antonio, take Highway 281 north. From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 east. By car to the LBJ Ranch and LBJ State Park and Historic Site: From Johnson City, take Highway 290 fourteen miles west to the LBJ State Park. From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 sixteen miles east to the LBJ State Park. The nearest major airports are in Austin and San Antonio.

operatingHours.description: The park is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. For hours specific to visitor centers and tours of historic buildings please see descriptions elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Johnson City District

operatingHours.description:
The LBJ Ranch is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. For hours specific to visitor centers and tours of historic buildings please see descriptions elsewhere.

To enter the LBJ Ranch you must pick up a free driving permit no later than 4:00 pm at the LBJ State Park and Historic Site visitor center.
operatingHours.name: LBJ Ranch

images.credit: LBJ Library Photo by Frank Wolfe
images.title: President and Mrs. Johnson with Yuki in front of the Texas White House
images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson stand with their small, white dog in front of the Texas White House.
images.caption: The Johnsons pose with their dog Yuki in front of the Texas White House. This was one of several photos from which they would choose for their 1972 Christmas card.

images.title: Texas White House
images.altText: View of Texas White House from front lawn.
images.caption: Because President Johnson spent one-fourth of his term a president in Texas, the press referred to this home as the "Texas White House"

images.title: Boyhood Home
images.altText: View of a one-story, white-frame house surrounded by a white picket fence.
images.caption: Lyndon Johnson was 5 years old when he moved to this home with his family. His childhood in a small rural town had great impact on his futur.

images.title: Touring the LBJ Ranch
images.altText: A brown and white Hereford calf stands alongside the road as a car approaches from behind.
images.caption: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.

images.title: Cyclists in the LBJ 100
images.altText: Luci Johnson (center in gray jersey) leads a bike tour
images.caption: Many special events, such as the LBJ 100 bike ride, take place during the year.

images.title: Gravestones for Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson
images.altText: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson
images.caption: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson

images.credit: LBJ Library Photo by Frank Wolfe
images.title: Portrait of the Johnsons
images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson stand outside the Texas White House with dog Yuki.
images.caption: For their 1972 Christmas card, the Johnsons stand outside the Texas White House with their dog Yuki.

images.title: Pedernales River
images.altText: The Pedernales River with tree-lined banks under a blue sky dotted with clouds.
images.caption: The Pedernales River forms flows past the LBJ Ranch

images.title: Lockheed Jetstar
images.altText: An exterior view of a White and blue jet with presidential seal painted just below the cockpit.
images.caption: One of the five Lockheed Jetstars in service during the Johnson Presidency is now on display at the LBJ Ranch..

data.weatherInfo: Overall, the park enjoys a sunny, mild climate during three seasons of the year. Spring: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Rain is common in April and May. Summer: Temperatures range from 70 F to 95 F (21 C/35 C). Temperatures can exceed 100 F (38 C) in July and August. Lightweight clothing and sunscreen are advisable. Be prepared with plenty of water. Fall: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 65 F (2 C/18 C) . Snow and ice are rare.
data.name: Lyndon B Johnson

data.description: Protecting sixty-six miles of wild coastline along the Gulf of Mexico, the narrow barrier island is home to one of the last intact coastal prairie habitats in the United States. Along the hypersaline Laguna Madre, unique tidal mud flats teem with life. Native Americans, Spanish explorers and cattle ranchers have walked along its shores. Padre Island National Seashore is waiting to be rediscovered.

emailAddresses.description: This is the primary park e-mail address for visitors to ask questions and get information about the park.

entranceFees.description: Admits the passholder and up to 15 passengers in the same private (non-commercial) vehicle. It expires at midnight on the day of purchase. This pass is not valid for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle 1-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits the passholder and passenger of one motorcycle. It expires at midnight on the day of purchase. This pass is not valid for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle 1-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual bicyclist, hiker, or pedestrian visiting the facility without a private vehicle. An individual pass is not required for visitors aged 15 and under. It expires at midnight on the day of purchase. This pass is not valid for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Pedestrian/Bicyclist 1-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits the passholder and up to 15 passengers in the same private (non-commercial) vehicle. It expires one week from the date of purchase. For private vehicles, this entrance pass is required for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Private Vehicle 7-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits the passholder and passenger of one motorcycle. It expires one week from the date of purchase. For motorcyclists, this entrance pass is required for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle 7-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual bicyclist, hiker, or pedestrian visiting the facility without a private vehicle. An individual pass is not required for visitors aged 15 and under. It expires one week from the date of purchase. For an individual, this entrance pass is required for overnight camping.
entranceFees.title: Pedestrian/Bicyclist 7-Day Pass

entranceFees.description: Allows one private vehicle and/or trailer to park at the Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp. It expires at midnight on the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp 1-Day Pass

entrancePasses.description: Admits the passholder and up to 15 passengers in the same private (non-commercial) vehicle or motorcycle. It expires one year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Padre Island Annual Pass

entrancePasses.description: Allows one private vehicle and/or trailer to park at the Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp. Valid one year from the month of purchase.
entrancePasses.title: Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp Annual Pass

data.directionsInfo: The National Seashore is located on North Padre Island, southeast of the city of Corpus Christi, Texas. Visitors to the area should head east through Corpus Christi on Highway 358. After crossing the JFK Causeway onto Padre Island, Highway 358 changes to Park Road 22. Continue about 10 miles south on Park Road 22 to reach the park entrance.

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year. However, park facilities are not open 24 hours per day. Hours for the entrance station, where the required entrance pass is sold, vary from day to day. If the entrance station is not open when you arrive, you can proceed into the park. If you are camping, go back to the entrance station the next morning and obtain an entrance pass. If not camping, pay the entrance fee as you leave if the entrance station is open.
operatingHours.name: Overall park access hours

images.title: A boy at play on scenic Padre Island
images.altText: A small boy plays at the water's edge on Padre Island
images.caption: Over 60 miles of beach offers beautiful scenery and fun for the whole family.

images.title: Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings
images.altText: Tiny Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings crawl on the beach of Padre Island.
images.caption: Thousands of visitors come to the park each summer to watch newborn Kemp's ridley sea turtle hatchlings get released into the Gulf of Mexico.

images.title: Black Skimmer
images.altText: A black skimmer flies by, slicing the surf with its lower bill to catch food.
images.caption: Over 380 bird species have been found at the park, making it a top destination for birders from around the world.

images.title: Camping on Padre Island
images.altText: A tent is set up close to the beach on Padre Island.
images.caption: Camping in a tent or RV is one of the most popular activities on Padre Island.

images.title: Sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island
images.altText: A beautiful and colorful sunrise over the Gulf of Mexico on Padre Island.
images.caption: Breathtaking sunrises, remote beaches, and dark night skies make Padre Island a top vacation destination.

images.title: Bird Island Basin Boat Ramp
images.altText: A woman drives a boat up to the ramp at Bird Island Basin.
images.caption: Bird Island Basin offers access to the Laguna Madre for boating, fishing, windsurfing, kayaking, and camping.

images.title: Fishing at Mansfield Channel
images.altText: A man in waders fishes in the surf along the Mansfield Channel jetties.
images.caption: Surf fishing is a great way to enjoy the outdoors at Padre Island National Seashore.

images.title: Big Shell Beach at Padre Island National Seashore
images.altText: Large seashells in front of the turquoise blue waters of the Gulf of mexico
images.caption: Padre Island National Seashore has over 70 miles of undeveloped coastline with ample beachcombing opportunities.

data.weatherInfo: Padre Island has long, hot summers and short, mild winters. Summers are very humid. Winter can bring strong cold fronts and gale force winds. Most rain falls near the beginning and end of hurricane season (Jun 1 - Nov 30). Average seasonal temperatures (Fahrenheit): Spring - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Summer - high mid-90s, low 70s; Fall - high 70s-80s, low 50s-60s; Winter - high 50s-70s, low 30s-40s. Year-round, average wind speed ranges from 5-25 miles per hour. Relative humidity seldom drops below 70%.
data.name: Padre Island

data.fullName: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park
data.description: On May 8, 1846, United States and Mexican troops clashed on the prairie of Palo Alto. The battle was the first in a two-year long war that changed the map of North America. Palo Alto Battlefield National Historical Park preserves the site of this notable battle and provides an understanding of the causes, events, and consequences of the U.S.-Mexican War.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee to enter Palo Alto Battlefield or attend park programs and events. Enjoy your visit!
entranceFees.title: No admission fee

data.directionsInfo: The park is located on Brownsville's north side, near the city of Los Fresnos. It is just north of the intersection of FM 1847 (Paredes Line Rd.) and FM 511/FM 550.

operatingHours.description: The park is open daily from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. but please note the Visitor Center is closed on Mondays. The park's busy season runs from November through May. During the month of May, the visitor center and trails are often busy with school field trips in the mornings. Park trails close at 4:30 p.m. All gates are locked at 5 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Palo Alto Battlefield

operatingHours.description: The site officially closes at dusk and is closed on all federal holidays.
operatingHours.name: Resaca de la Palma Battlefield Unit

images.title: Battlefield overlook
images.altText: Shaded structure overlooking the battlefield
images.caption: The overlook gives you a great view of the battlefield

images.title: Sunrise
images.altText: Sun rising over the battlefield
images.caption: Get here when the park opens and enjoy views like this.

images.title: Sunset over the battlefield
images.altText: Sunset over the battlefield
images.caption: Early sunsets during winter are a sight to behold.

images.title: Mexican 8-pounder
images.altText: Mexican 8-pounder cannon on the battlefield.
images.caption: A Mexican 8-pound field gun surveys the battlefield.

images.title: Visitor Center
images.altText: Front view of Visitor Center
images.caption: Stop by the Visitor Center before heading out on the trail.

data.weatherInfo: Summers are hot and humid. Tropical weather systems generally affect the area from August to October. Winters are usually mild but cold fronts can drop temperatures by up to 30 degrees in about an hour.
data.name: Palo Alto Battlefield

data.description: For 196 miles, this free-flowing stretch of the Rio winds its way through desert expanses and stunning canyons of stratified rock. For the well prepared, an extended float trip provides opportunities to explore the most remote corner of Texas and experience the ultimate in solitude, self-reliance, and immersion in natural soundscapes.

entranceFees.description:
To access the Rio Grande Wild & Scenic River, you will enter Big Bend National Park. Entrance fees apply. 

Big Bend Entrance Fee--Per Vehicle - $30.00
This fee includes all occupants of a private, non-commercial vehicle and is valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Big Bend National Park Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Several highways lead to Big Bend National Park: TX 118 from Alpine to Study Butte or FM 170 from Presidio to Study Butte (then 26 miles east to park headquarters) or US 90 or US 385 to Marathon (then 70 miles south to park headquarters). Distances between towns and services are considerable. Be sure you have plenty of gas, food, water, and supplies for your trip.

operatingHours.description: Rio Grande Wild & Scenic River is open 24 hours a day, 365 days per year.
operatingHours.name: Rio Grande Wild & Scenic River

images.caption: A float through the canyons can be a magical experience.

images.altText: People in two canoes paddle on a river threading through high canyon walls.

images.caption: The Rio Grande seen from the Santa Elena River Access.

data.weatherInfo: Variable -- February-April: High temperatures range from mid-70sF (23C) to low-90sF (32C) with lows from the mid-30sF (2C) to mid-50sF (12C). Cold fronts can bring freezing weather with rain or snow. -- May-August: Temperatures are hot and the weather can be stormy. Temperatures over 100F (more than 38C) degrees. -- September-January:Temperatures are cooler. The weather can turn cold any time during these months.
data.name: Rio Grande

data.fullName: San Antonio Missions National Historical Park
data.description: Welcome to San Antonio Missions, a National Park Service site and the only UNESCO World Heritage Site in Texas. After 10,000 years, the people of South Texas were faced with drought, European diseases, and colonization. In the early 1700s, many Native people of South Texas foreswore their traditional life to become Spanish, accepting a new religion and agrarian lifestyle in hopes of survival.

entranceFees.description: Entrance to the park is free. Es gratis.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Park Headquarter's is located 4 miles south of downtown San Antonio. The four mission sites lay as a chain south of downtown. Mission Concepción is 3 miles, Mission San José and the park visitor center is 6 miles south, Mission San Juan is 3 miles south of San José, and Mission Espada lays another mile beyond. Written directions and GPS addresses can be found at the link below.

operatingHours.description:
Park grounds are open sunrise to sunset. Mission San José is open 9am-5pm. 
Our park store located in the Visitor Center is open daily 9 am to 1 pm and 2 pm to 5 pm. 
Park grounds are closed on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: San Antonio Missions National Historical Park

operatingHours.description:
Mission San José is open 9 am to 5 pm. 
The Visitor Center at Mission San José includes the Park Store and an information desk. 
Visit the Visitor Center for park information or to pick up your Junior Ranger booklet! 
Park Store is located inside of the Visitor Center and is open 9 am to 1 pm and 2 pm to 5 pm, 7 days/week.
operatingHours.name: Mission San José

operatingHours.description: Contact Stations at the two southern mission sites, Mission Espada and Mission San Juan, open at 10:00 am.
operatingHours.name: Mission Espada and Mission San Juan

addresses.line1: Visitor Center at Mission San José

images.title: Mission Espada, World Heritage Site
images.altText: Mission Espada, World Heritage Site
images.caption: A part of Mission Espada's ranch is located 30 miles south-east, outside of Floresville, TX.

images.title: Tours of Mission San José
images.altText: Park Ranger leads a tour through Mission San José
images.caption: Catch a tour at Mission San José at 10:00, 11:00, 1:00 and 3:00 daily.

images.caption: The Rose Window is a famous feature of Mission San Jose.

images.title: Mission San Jose sunset

images.caption: Explore 18th century mission sites like Mission San Jose.

images.title: Mission Concepcion Convento & Church
images.altText: Mission Concepcion convento with church in background.
images.caption: Mission Concepcion is the nation's oldest unrestored stone church.

data.weatherInfo: Over the course of a year, the temperature typically varies from 40°F to 95°F and is rarely below 29°F or above 100°F. The warm season lasts from May through September with an average daily high temperature above 90°F and a low of 75°F. The cold season lasts from November through February with an average daily high below 68°F and an average low of 40°F. The relative humidity ranges from 40-80% over the course of the year, which can be very uncomfortable to many people.
data.name: San Antonio Missions

data.description: Standing as tall as 14 feet and weighing 20,000 pounds, Columbian mammoths roamed across what is present-day Texas thousands of years ago. Today, the fossil specimens represent the nation's first and only recorded evidence of a nursery herd of ice age Columbian mammoths.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to Waco Mammoth National Monument. There are guided tour fees.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a tour of the Dig Shelter where mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).
entranceFees.title: Guided Tour Fee - Adult

entranceFees.description:
This fee is for a tour of the Dig Shelter where mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).

The only access to the Dig Shelter is with a tour guide.

Length of tour - 45 minutes to one hour.
entranceFees.title: Guided Tour Fee - Senior (62+)

entranceFees.description:
This fee is for a tour of the Dig Shelter where mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).

The only access to the Dig Shelter is with a tour guide.

Length of tour - 45 minutes to one hour.
entranceFees.title: Guided Tour Fee - Military (with ID)

entranceFees.description: This fee is for a tour of the Dig Shelter where mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).
entranceFees.title: Guided Tour Fee - Youth (ages 4-17)

entranceFees.description:
This fee is for a tour of the Dig Shelter where mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).

The only access to the Dig Shelter is with a tour guide.

Length of tour - 45 minutes to one hour.
entranceFees.title: Guided Tour Fee - Infants (ages 3 and under)

data.directionsInfo: From I-35 North, take exit 339 and head west on Lake Shore Drive. Turn right on Steinbeck Bend Drive and travel 1.5 miles to the Monument. From I-35 South, take exit 335C and head northwest on Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard. Continue straight onto Steinbeck Bend Drive and travel 1.5 miles to the Monument. The Monument is easily accessible via personal vehicle, bus, or motor home.

operatingHours.description: Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day
operatingHours.name: Waco Mammoth National Monument

images.title: Interior of Dig Shelter
images.altText: Visitors view fossils from walkway
images.caption: Visitors view fossils from above using the elevated walkway.

images.credit: Official White House photo by Amanda Lucidon
images.title: Waco Mammoth Executive Order
images.altText: President Obama signs order viewed by members of National Park Service
images.caption: On July 10, 2015, President Barack Obama issued a Presidential Proclamation making the Waco Mammoth Site a new unit of the National Park System.

images.title: Mammoth Herd Mural
images.altText: Painting of Mammoth nursery herd
images.caption: This paleontological site represents the nation’s only recorded discovery of a nursery herd of Columbian mammoths.

images.title: Entrance Sign to Waco Mammoth
images.altText: Entrance sign to Waco Mammoth with bluebonnets in foreground.
images.caption: Waco Mammoth National Monument became part of the national Park Service on July 10, 2015.

images.title: Mammoth Tusks
images.altText: Mammoth Tusks in situ
images.caption: Mammoth fossils are in situ (still in their original position within the bone bed).

data.weatherInfo: The monument enjoys a sunny, mild climate during three seasons of the year. Spring: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Rain is common in April and May. Summer: Temperatures range from 70 F to 95 F (21 C/35 C). Temperatures can exceed 100 F (38 C) in July and August. Lightweight clothing and sunscreen are advisable. Be prepared with plenty of water. Fall: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 65 F (2 C/18 C) . Snow and ice are rare.
data.name: Waco Mammoth
